The communist nations, on the other hand, have a highly
skilled and experienced corps of propagandists hard at work
constantly promoting their interests. From such centers as
Moscow, Peiping, Pyongyang, and Vladivostok, regular and
frequent radio programs are beamed to the Japanese, Until
late last year, the Communists operated a station, ironically
called “Radio Free Japan11 devoted entirely to Japan and broad-
casting from Red China. Commercial trading companies,
dealing almost exclusively in material from the Communist
orbit, import large quantities of reading matter that is
sold for ridiculously low prices. It is often possible to
purchase a dozen high quality Communist magazines for the
price of one popular American magazine. In addition to the
Soviet Union and Red China, East Germany, Czechoslovakia,
Poland, Bulgaria, North Korea, and strangely enough, the
Communist Party of the United States have provided material
available to Tokyo’s millions and, :n considerably lesser
amounts, throughout the country. The secret of the Communist
tactic would appear to be their close cooperation with and
reliance upon local groups who do the actual spreading of
the material to the public.
There are, of course, anti-Communist publications, including
strong and influential dailies such as the “Tokyo Shimbun,”
In spite of their ingenuity .and industry, the Communists have
not gained the suppbrt thatmignfbe expected from their
activities.
In the final analysis, it must be remembered that Japan has
the most well informed, intelligent population in all of
Asia. They are not likely to be led astray easily. They
will make final decisions themselves.
